instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928A: What is 820-00928A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_CTL: What is SMC_FAN_0_CTL? SMC_FAN_0_CTL is a line between the SMC and the fan that controls fan speed that is frequently disturbed when someone inexperienced knocks resistors in the area off with their fingernail or screwdriver when unplugging the fan. .
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Hi,

I'll try to list everything I know so far:
[LIST=1]
[*]Draws ~1.1A @ 20V when powered (without battery)
[*]Draws ~330mA @ 20V when turned of with power button
[LIST=1]
[*]Kind of high right? but nothing gets hot, checked with IR camera
[/LIST]
[*]All _s0 power rails present
[*]Tried flashing 4 different bios images found on this board, no change
[*]Only once the boot logo was visible after SMC reset
[LIST=1]
[*]After that, the fans were always running at max
[*]Now after probing on some smc lines, the fans run normal (gradually revving up, but not to max)
[/LIST]
[*]No chime, caps lock light, usb activity, Touch Bar, external video
[*]Trackpad clicks
[*]No voltage drop at <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, stays at ~1.05V
[*]smc bypass mode won't work
[*]No reaction on multimeter or otherwise when trying PRAM reset
[*]History not known, but I can see it was worked on
[LIST=1]
[*]A line is soldered from <RESISTOR>R6001</RESISTOR>[2] to it's probe point (<SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL>) slightly below 
[/LIST]
[/LIST]

Where to go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
330mA for a board in S5 state, is really high.
You should find the reason.
Remove F7000 and check again the current.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I guess you mean both F7000 and F7001, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Yeah, didn't look at schematic; big boards have 2 fuses on parallel.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
At the top I said, all power rails present, but actually <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 12.59V, which is ok for other boards, but not this, right?
Now after removing the fuses, the usb-c multimeter says 350mA @20V and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still 12.59V.
When measuring <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> I get 21.2V although the usb-c multimeter actually says 19.3V. Don't know if that's significant.
I measured around the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> and got these values:
<SIGNAL>GATE_Q4</SIGNAL>: 0V
LX2:          0V
Boot2:      5V
<SIGNAL>GATE_Q3</SIGNAL>: 5V
<SIGNAL>GATE_Q2</SIGNAL>: 5V
Boot2:      5V
LX1:          0V
<SIGNAL>GATE_Q1</SIGNAL>: 0V
No shorts to ground on the caps.
On L7030 I get 0.02V on both sides.

Are these values normal. Sorry for asking basic stuff. I don't have a working <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
You still have high current without the fuses.
I can suppose a problem through <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.
Some chip sinks too much current there probably.
Could be SMC, or PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Without the fuses the PCH stays cold and the SMC is barely (~1Â°C) warmer then room temperature.
With the fuses the PCH gets almost as hot as the CPU. The SMC stays as before.
Any way to rule out or confine without blindly replacing those two?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: In such case, you should have bigger current difference between the two cases; w/ and w/o fuses on board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Sorry, that wasn't clear. The PCH only gets hot when it's trying to turn on. When I turn it off by pressing the power button, it's as if the fuses were removed, except without fuses it's drawing 20mA more.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Do you get the same current on USB-C meter in all 4 ports (in S5 state)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Yes. 
Also, when I do an SMC reset, the current goes down to 350mA (like without fuses) while pressing the key combo and after letting go. Than it won't turn on (draw more amps) anymore unless I replug the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Some chip sinks too much current from <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
